summary: **noun / manufacturing grade.** A record pressed from 100% new PVC compound.
definition: **noun / manufacturing grade.** A record pressed from 100% new polyvinyl chloride (PVC) compound with no recycled re-grind material, resulting in cleaner surfaces and lower noise floors. Virgin vinyl became a quality marker in the 1970s as cost-cutting measures led many plants to blend factory floor scraps and recycled records back into the pressing compound, creating a two-tier manufacturing standard. Pure virgin compound produces deeper, quieter grooves with less surface noise, fewer non-fill defects, and better high-frequency response. Audiophile labels like Mobile Fidelity, Analogue Productions, and Classic Records prominently advertised virgin vinyl formulations throughout the 1980s-2000s reissue boom, often combined with heavy-weight pressings (180g-200g) to signal premium quality. Modern pressing plants typically reserve virgin compound for deluxe editions and audiophile releases, while standard retail pressings may contain 10-30% re-grind to control costs. Collectors can sometimes identify virgin pressings by their deeper black color and slightly glossier finish, though formulation opacity makes visual confirmation unreliable without manufacturer documentation.
etymology: Term emerged in 1970s pressing industry to distinguish new PVC compound from cost-saving recycled blends, borrowed from petrochemical industry terminology for unprocessed polymers.
